details.title: On-Line Reliability Prediction via Dynamic Failure Rate Model

authors.affiliation: Lab. de Tribologie et de Dynamique des Syst., CNRS, St.-Etienne

p: Rosario Toscano was born in Catania, Italy, on 28 September 1962. He received his engineering degree from the Conservatoire National des Arts et Métiers (CNAM) in March 1994. He received his masters degree with specialization in control from the Institut National des Sciences Appliquées de Lyon (INSA, National Institute for Applied Sciences), in June 1996. He received the Ph.D. degree from the Ecole Centrale de Lyon in November 2000. He received the HDR degree (Habilitation to Direct Research) from University of Jean Monnet of Saint-Etienne in December 2007. He is currently an Associate Professor at the Ecole Nationale d'Ingénieurs de Saint-Etienne (ENISE). His research interests in the Laboratory of Tribology and Dynamical Systems (LTDS) include fault detection, robust control, and multimodel approach applied to diagnosis and control.

authors.name: Rosario Toscano

authors.affiliation: Lab. de Tribologie et de Dynamique des Syst., CNRS, St.-Etienne

p: Patrick Lyonnet is currently a Professor at the Ecole Nationale d'Ingénieurs de Saint-Etienne (ENISE). His research interests are in the Laboratory of Tribology and Dynamical Systems (LTDS UMR 5513) include fault detection, reliability, and the maintenance of industrial systems. He is an active member of the institute of management of the risk.

authors.name: Patrick Lyonnet

details.abstract: This paper presents a new dynamic reliability approach which is able to take into account the various operating conditions under which the considered system has evolved (past and present). To this end, we propose a differential model of failure rate, combined with the state space representation of the process, as well as a parameterization procedure. A numerical example shows the practical applicability of the proposed approach.

references.title:
Feedback control of multiinput nonlinear
systems by extended linearization

context.text: The classical Luenberger observer can be extended to nonlinear systems via extended linearization [1].
The details for the determination of the function \${\bf g}(.,.)\$ are given in [1].

links.abstract: Control of a nonlinear system is addressed by considering its family of linearizations. Given that a family of linear state-feedback controllers has been designed to meet some (linear) control objective, it is shown how these controllers can be pieced together into an overall, nonlinear, state-feedback controller. The resulting closed-loop system has the property that its linearizations are equal to the desired linearly controlled systems. A similar approach can be used to design nonlinear state...

references.text: W. T. Baumann, "Feedback control of multiinput nonlinear systems by extended linearization", IEEE Trans. Automatic Control, vol. 33, pp. 193-197, 1988.

degradation: a case study

context.text: These data can then be used for the parameterization of models reflecting population characteristics, under the same conditions as those constituted in the data [2], [3], [5], [6], [9].

links.abstract: An analysis strategy (experimental and analytic) for extracting reliability information from the measured degradation of devices subjected to elevated stress is described. The strategy is applied to the estimation of the reliability of an integrated logic family that is a component of a new generation of submarine cables. The experiment consisted of monitoring several electrical parameters while aging the devices under elevated temperature. The authors model changes observed in one of these elec...

references.text: M. B. Carey, R. H. Koening, "Reliability assessment based on accelerated degradation: a case study", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 40, pp. 499-560, 1991.

references.title: Observing the state of a linear system

context.text: In the case of linear systems, the observer design theory, developed by Lunberger [4], offers a complete, comprehensive answer to this problem.

links.abstract: In much of modern control theory designs are based on the assumption that the state vector of the system to be controlled is available for measurement. In many practical situations only a few output quantities are available. Application of theories which assume that the state vector is known is severely limited in these cases. In this paper it is shown that the state vector of a linear system can be reconstructed from observations of the system inputs and outputs. It is shown that the observer, ...

references.text: D. G. Luenberger, "Observing the state of a linear system", IEEE Trans. Military Electronics, vol. 8, pp. 74-80, 1964.

references.title:
Analysis of performance-degradation data
from accelerated tests

context.text: These data can then be used for the parameterization of models reflecting population characteristics, under the same conditions as those constituted in the data [2], [3], [5], [6], [9].

links.abstract: The performance of many products degrades as the product ages. Such degradation is usually slow but can be accelerated by a high `stress'. For example, the breakdown strength of electrical insulation depends on age and temperature. In some tests, the performance of a test unit is measured only once at a chosen age. For example, an insulation specimen yields only one breakdown measurement. A model and analyses for such data are described in this tutorial article. Also described is a method for es...

references.text: W. Nelson, "Analysis of performance-degradation data from accelerated tests", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 30, pp. 149-155, 1981.

references.title:
Upper and lower bounds of stress-strength interference reliability
with random strength-degradation

context.text: These data can then be used for the parameterization of models reflecting population characteristics, under the same conditions as those constituted in the data [2], [3], [5], [6], [9].

links.abstract: A stress-strength interference reliability model with strength degradation is established under the assumptions: stress and strength are statistically independent; dynamic loading forces follow a Poisson-process and Gaussian distribution; and random strength-degradation is described by distribution parameter regression models. Simple formulas for estimating upper and lower bounds for strength-stress interference reliability are presented. The results can be applied to reliability estimation in w...

references.text: J. Xue, K. Yang, "Upper and lower bounds of stress-strength interference reliability with random strength-degradation", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 46, pp. 142-145, 1997.

references.title: Real-time performance reliability prediction

context.text: This approach is in contrast with the work presented in [7], [8] in which the reliability prediction is based on the assumption that there are some measurable variables reflecting directly the degradation of the system.

links.abstract: The purpose of this paper is to describe an approach to real-time reliability prediction, applicable to an individual product unit, operating under dynamic conditions. The concept of conditional reliability estimation is extended to real-time applications using time-series analysis techniques to bridge the gap between physical measurement and reliability prediction. The model is based on empirical measurements, self-generating, and applicable to online applications. This approach has been demons...

references.text: H. Lu, W. J. Kolarik, S. S. Lu, "Real-time performance reliability prediction", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 50, pp. 353-357, 2001.

references.title: Maintenance Planning

context.text: These data can then be used for the parameterization of models reflecting population characteristics, under the same conditions as those constituted in the data [2], [3], [5], [6], [9].
These relations allows us, by using usual techniques of Weibull law parameterization (see [9]), to define, point by point, the unknown functions \$n({\bf x},{\bf u})\$, and \$\psi({\bf x},{\bf u})\$.
The detail of the procedure on how to obtain \$\beta({\mmb\xi}_{i})\$ and \$\eta({\mmb\xi}_{i})\$ from \${\cal L}_{i}\$ is well known, and is therefore omitted (one can see [9] for the details).

references.text: P. Lyonnet, Maintenance Planning, 1991, Chapman & Hall.
